I won't stop you from leaving
I know that I'm not what you wanted, am I?

Now you think I'm not trying

Maybe it's all gonna turn out all right

I have to believe that it is
I have to believe that it is
(I have to believe it, I have to believe it)
I have to believe that it is

description.plain:
This is the first track to be released from Baker’s second LP Turn Out The Lights. It was released alongside the album pre-order on August 17, 2017.

The song describes a breakdown in a relationship, either due to mental health issues or drug addiction (which Baker has covered in previous songs). The song incorporates a lot more instrumentation than previous songs from Baker, including guitar, piano and ambient additions as well as multiple vocal lines.

The music video was released on September 14, 2017:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MdBu21i9aEE9

body.plain:
This is the first track to be released from Baker’s second LP Turn Out The Lights. It was released alongside the album pre-order on August 17, 2017.

The song describes a breakdown in a relationship, either due to mental health issues or drug addiction (which Baker has covered in previous songs). The song incorporates a lot more instrumentation than previous songs from Baker, including guitar, piano and ambient additions as well as multiple vocal lines.

The music video was released on September 14, 2017:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MdBu21i9aEE9

annotations:
Suggest that I talk to somebody again
 That knows how to help me get better

Often someone who is trying to help someone going through a depressive episode will suggest professional help.

There are a number of ways a depressed person might react to this; by saying they don’t need it or deserve it, that other people need it more, by interpreting it as the other person giving up on them and giving them up to someone else, or resigning themselves to it to appease the other person. The final one is the one that happens here.

She can’t miss any more appointments if she wants to get better – but being depressed certainly doesn’t help you keep them.

You don’t have to remind me so much
 How I disappoint you

The other person would never tell her she’s disappointing them, but that’s how she feels when she is reminded of her shortcomings.

Often in a depressive episode, the self-hatred is worsened by someone else being aware of the lack of motivation, lack of improvement and lack of self-care. The depressed person can interpret this awareness or concern as disappointment.

She knows they want her to get better, but she’s disappointing them by not doing it, and it’s making her feel worse. It’s a vicious circle.

You don’t want to bring it up
 And I already know how it looks

She understands why the other person won’t talk about it, she knows that they’re trying to protect her feelings, trying to not to make the situation worse.

Often it’s hard to help someone else who is struggling by not being all they can be. Pointing out the things they’re doing wrong can make them feel worse.

She knows how it looks – she knows that they don’t see her trying to improve, and that it might mean that she doesn’t care. The next line then focuses on the way this makes her feel.
I know that I’m not what you wanted, am I?

In the context of the song, she’s confronting them, letting them know she’s aware of how they feel about her. She knows they have realised she is a different person than they thought.

Baker explained in the Song Exploder podcast that these lyrics were the first idea for the song:

I felt an inadequacy or an imposter syndrome when I would talk with my friends or when I would be at a party standing around. I would just have this bizarre paranoia that I’m not what any of these people wanted and I’m disappointing and I’m letting everyone down. And that recurring thought was probably the first idea that cropped up in my brain for the lyrics.

And when I tell you that it is
 Oh, it’s more for my benefit

As is apparent with ‘Hurt Less’, too, and ‘Sour Breath’ to an extent, an important part of Turn Out the Lights is the impact of Julien leaning on other people. It seems here that she’s admitting that her informing her partner (or whatever relationship is occurring) about her wellbeing is for her own benefit, and not for the other’s peace of mind. .
She is stating that she’s telling people she’s fine so that hopefully she starts to believe it herself.
Her saying that things are alright is her trying to believe it herself and is her last grasp at hope.

Maybe it’s all gonna turn out all right
 Oh, I know that it’s not, but I have to believe that it is

Here Baker admits defeat again, going from “I know that it’s not” to “probably not” and back again.

The difference between knowing and believing could also show the internal struggle of keeping one’s faith.

Maybe it’s all gonna turn out all right
 And I know that it’s not, but I have to believe that it is
 
 [Bridge]
 I have to believe that it is
 I have to believe that it is
 (I have to believe it, I have to believe it)
 I have to believe that it is
 (Probably not, but I have to believe that it is)

This dichotomy is what depressives often have to deal with. To keep their head above water they must be positive and be forward looking, knowing things will improve. However, the darker thoughts tell them that it probably won’t be the case.

Here Baker puts those things against each other, repeating the cycle like a mantra in a way that echoes the feeling one has whilst struggling internally to fight against personal demons to try and stay happy.

I think if I fail again
 That I know you’re still listening
Her failure here is either relapse or a fall into a depressive state. She hopes that God is still listening to her prayers even if this happens.

Nothing turns out like I pictured it
 Maybe the emptiness is just a lesson in canvases

Baker takes the metaphor of the picture in her mind and extends it here.
She hasn’t imagined that this would be the way it turns out but the emptiness – or loneliness – of the canvas – or her life – might be a lesson for her.

And ’til then I should just try not to miss any more
 Appointments

Some people with mental health issues, particularly depressives, have a hard time leaving their bed, room, or house. Its such an effort just to get out of bed that making an appointment seems and often times is, an impossible task. Since she is not better yet, her partner is suggesting that she at least make it to her appointments. For a non-depressive this seems like an easy ask, but for a depressive this ask seems extreme and impossible.

description.plain:
Julien Baker’s first single from her upcoming album Little Oblivions. The track premiered and was accompanied by an interview in Rolling Stone on the October 21st, 2020.

The track details how easy it is to relapse into using drugs again. The faith healer or the snake oil dealer – both who peddle healing abilities, but may not be entirely trustworthy – is the drug dealer, bringing release to a pained user.

song.title: Faith Healer

body.plain:
Julien Baker’s first single from her upcoming album Little Oblivions. The track premiered and was accompanied by an interview in Rolling Stone on the October 21st, 2020.

The track details how easy it is to relapse into using drugs again. The faith healer or the snake oil dealer – both who peddle healing abilities, but may not be entirely trustworthy – is the drug dealer, bringing release to a pained user.

songs.full_title: Faith Healer (Half Waif Remix) by Julien Baker
songs.title: Faith Healer (Half Waif Remix)

annotations:
Oh, what I wouldn’t give if it would take away the sting a minute
 Everything I love, I’d trade it in to feel it rush into my chest

This gets at the idea that, given the re-wired circuitry of the brain’s reward centers, addicts are predisposed to making decisions in favor of the short-acting, immediate pleasures (such as using drugs) to the detriment of more long-lasting stability (“Everything I love, I’d trade it in”). Julien’s existential angst (and the feeling of real life being “startling[ly] intens[e]” in the absence of drugs) is too much to bear, such that she’d give up the newfound stability she’s earned from her sobriety to make it go away.

The smoke alarm’s been going off for weeks
 No one showed up and half the time it isn’t what you think of

Unlike immediately pressing and urgent threats to one’s life or livelihood (which often see tragedy immediately follow the first warning), the struggle that Julien is having has manifested itself more slowly, the first signs emerging “weeks” ago, with an insidious nature to the point that she is consciously ignoring them (“half the time it isn’t what you think of”).

Similarly, we see a juxtaposition between a smoke alarm (usually a sign of imminent danger and a need for immediate help) and the fact that there has been no rush from an external figure (God, friends, loved ones) to come help (“No one showed up”). This hell in which she’s living is a more subacute, drawn-out, solitary hell that she feels almost lazy about addressing, given the slow build.
[Verse 1]

In an interview with KEXP, Baker states “I wrote the very beginning of [Faith Healer] about the longing that addiction that creates … the substances we use, the escapist mentalities we have, the negative coping mechanisms, these are all ways that we create little tiny oblivions in our head because reality is difficult and painful.”

https://youtu.be/HS2TxfBSmjs
A snake oil dealer

Snake oil is a substance with no real medicinal value sold as a remedy for all diseases. The term is often used to describe something that is offered as the solution to a problem, but in reality does little or nothing to help.

In this sense, Baker could saying that the “faith healer”/preacher offers solace but in reality what the preacher says does not help her.
I’ll believe you if you make me feel something

In her interview with Pitchfork, Julien states, “I (and so many other people) are willing to believe whomever—a political pundit, a preacher, a drug dealer, an energy healer—when they promise healing, and how that willingness, however genuine, might actually impede healing.”

https://pitchfork.com/news/julien-baker-announces-new-album-little-oblivions-shares-new-song-listen/

Ooh, I miss it high, how it dulled the terror and the beauty
 And now I see everything in startling intensity

In her interview with Pitchfork, Julien states, “Put most simply, I think that “Faith Healer” is a song about vices, both the obvious and the more insidious ways that they show up in the human experience. I started writing this song 2 years ago and it began as a very literal examination of addiction. For awhile, I only had the first verse, which is just a really candid confrontation of the cognitive dissonance a person who struggles with substance abuse can feel—the overwhelming evidence that this substance is harming you, and the counterintuitive but very real craving for the relief it provides.”

https://pitchfork.com/news/julien-baker-announces-new-album-little-oblivions-shares-new-song-listen/
Faith healer, come put your hands on me

Faith healers hold a controversial role in evangelical Christianity, as well as other faiths and doctrines.

Whilst some have no doubt about their miraculous healing hands, others doubt their true abilities – especially when their hands are outstretched to take money before or after they have healed.

In this song, Julien Baker is asking to be healed but not by anyone who is trustworthy, more by someone who can make her believe she is being cured or fixing what is broken when in fact they may be doing nothing at all.

Many believe faith healers are an example of the “placebo” effect, where cures and healings are in fact wrapped up in the mind of the cured or healed. Julien Baker wants to only believe she is getting better, rather than being treated by someone who could actually fix her.

[Verse 2]

Is it real or a dream, which is worse?

[Bridge]
(When I turn out the lights)
When I turn out the lights
There's no one left
Between myself and me

[Chorus]
But when I turn out the lights
When I turn out the lights
When I turn out the lights, oh
There's no one left
Between myself and meYou might also like5Embed

description.plain:
This song is about dealing with problems on your own, but realising that when it comes down to it you only have yourself to rely on. By turning out the lights, you’re alone and you have to deal with things alone.

In an interview with Face Culture, Baker explained how the song externalized the feelings she experienced while on tour. She said, “I think writing that song and externalizing how I was feeling: that I was feeling isolated and saying, like, you know, “whenever it’s time to go to bed, and I turn out the lights, I have to confront all the parts of myself that I haven’t quite come to terms with yet” helped me do that. It helped me confront the things about myself that I might think are ugly or a problem and realize that I can embrace those things.”

The official video was released on 11th October 2017 and depicts Baker following a fuse to a burning piano.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xV1dMqeb4_U

body.plain:
This song is about dealing with problems on your own, but realising that when it comes down to it you only have yourself to rely on. By turning out the lights, you’re alone and you have to deal with things alone.

In an interview with Face Culture, Baker explained how the song externalized the feelings she experienced while on tour. She said, “I think writing that song and externalizing how I was feeling: that I was feeling isolated and saying, like, you know, “whenever it’s time to go to bed, and I turn out the lights, I have to confront all the parts of myself that I haven’t quite come to terms with yet” helped me do that. It helped me confront the things about myself that I might think are ugly or a problem and realize that I can embrace those things.”

The official video was released on 11th October 2017 and depicts Baker following a fuse to a burning piano.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xV1dMqeb4_U

annotations:
I’m not always like this
 There’s always tomorrow I guess

A well known theme amongst those who suffer from depression is the discomfort of the monotony that they can’t seem to break. In fact, there is a popular meme associated with depression; “Everyday I put on my silly little  and do my silly little _.

Say you wish you could find some way to help
 Not to be so hard on myself
 So why is it easy for everyone else?

This line is a conversation (of sorts) between Julien and her friends/support circles.

The support her friends are offering suggest that it must be so easy for them to overcome the emotional turmoil that Julien’s currently experiencing.

They offer their sentiments and condolences, wishing they “could find some way to help.” They try to tell her to stop being so critical of herself.

Julien’s experience with this advice is clearly that it’s easier said than done. Her friends can instruct her to keep her chin up, but it’s not so easy for her. Arguably, these empty encouragements are making her feel worse – more alone and further gone, since everyone else seems to have a much easier time overcoming their struggles.

(When I turn out the lights)
 When I turn out the lights
 There’s no one left
 Between myself and me
 
 [Chorus]
 But when I turn out the lights
 When I turn out the lights
 When I turn out the lights, oh
 There’s no one left
 Between myself and me

Baker is saying that with all the lights turned off, with no one else around and with nothing else there, she is alone with herself and her thoughts.

No one is there to stop her from being consumed by the bad thoughts she’s already talked about.

Also brings to mind Shel Silverstein’s poem “No Difference” in which each couplet ends with “when we turn off the light”. In the poem, darkness similarly brings relief in contrast to light which provides people the ability to see and judge each other.

I can’t tell the difference when I’m all alone
 Is it real or a dream, which is worse?
 Can you help me?
 I just wanted to go to sleep

She’s feeling suicidal and when she’s all alone she can’t tell whether she really wants to die or not. She is unsure it is worse to feel like she wants to die when she doesn’t or actually want to die. She’s reaching out for help because she’s feeling suicidal but is afraid to die.
And I’d never do it but it’s not a joke

Here, Julien is talking about suicide.

She’s saying that she’d never kill herself, but her feelings of depression and wanting to die (“go to sleep”) are so prevalent that it’s not a joke, either.

There’s a hole in the drywall still not fixed
 I just haven’t gotten around to it
 And besides I’m starting to get used to the gaps

She’s using the hole in drywall as an allegory to a hole in a life caused by depression. Depression makes small tasks seem overwhelming, and eventually leads to a point where you become numb to the problems you won’t address. Julien is saying that she knows there is something glaringly wrong in her life but she is either able to look past it or refuses to really even acknowledge it.

From the grill of your truck

With anything less than human

Doesn't feel too good, either
Just like a nicotine patch, it
Hardly works, then it's over

Who put me
In your way to find?
And what right had you
Not to let me die?

What I was asking for?
If I had my way
I'd have missed you more
Than you missed me
You missed me
You might also like[Outro]
You missed me
You missed me7Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Favor” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Favor

annotations:
Sat on the hood, out all night
 Trying to scrape together change

This line has two meanings:

1) People trying to scrape together change (especially at night) are often impoverished addicts desperate for a fix. This illustrates Julien’s state of mind, and also references her struggles with substance abuse.

2) “Change” can mean loose coins, but it can also mean “alteration.” That is to say, Julien is trying to find a way to change her situation, but without many signs of hope.

You pulled a moth out
 From the grill of your truck
 Saying it’s a shame

Moths are notorious for drawing themselves into fatal positions due to a lack of understanding regarding the consequences of their actions. Julien likely sees herself as the moth for replicating similar behaviors.

It doesn’t feel too bad, but it
 Doesn’t feel too good, either
 Just like a nicotine patch, it
 Hardly works, then it’s over

Being vulnerable with others while attempting to recover your ability to trust others is a difficult task. At times, it can feel revelatory and freeing to finally trust a person enough to tell them about your problems. However, at the same time, these feeling often do not last or the self-discovery fails to elicit any lasting impact on the person. Recovering from broken trust is a non-linear process, a process Julien must continue to traverse with the people who care about her.

I always wanna tell the truth
 But it never seems like the right time
 To be serious enough
 I’m sorry I’m making myself cry

While Julien wishes she could be vulnerable with the ones who care about her, she does not allow herself to be since she does not wish to burden them with her dark emotions or make them pity her when she feels she has caused them pain. To Julien, it feels wrong for these individuals to empathize with her if she has wronged them. The guilt of making the ones she cares about feel this way coupled with her own self-hatred for her actions makes these kinds of disclosures difficult for Julien to make.

How long do I have until
 I’ve spent up everyone’s goodwill?

This is a sentiment I also share. Hurting your friends, loved ones or just the people around you for whatever reason, feeling guilty/ashamed, and wanting to make it up to them but not knowing how many chances you have left, or feeling like they’re already fed up with you and could leave at any second.

Alternatively, this could mean wanting to be better but not knowing how long it could take to improve.

Who put me
 In your way to find?
 And what right had you
 Not to let me die?
 Ooh, but did I even know
 What I was asking for?
 If I had my way

She illuminates how important this person/these people were in keeping her alive when she wanted to die. The tone suggests almost a resentment for that, reminiscent of when she asked a similar question of God on Rejoice:

 Why did you let them leave and then make me stay?

The twist is that despite how much her depression and suicidal thoughts were dragging her down, she now realizes that she did not fully understand the consequences that dying would have.

I’d have missed you more
 Than you missed me
 You missed me

Reminiscent of the outro to her song Decorated Lawns where she seems to put her love of others above her self:

I loved you
More than I hate me

As well as of Conversation Piece:

But you always say you would miss me
Who am I kidding?
Even if I meant it
I’d probably still visit

How come it’s so much easier
 With anything less than human
 Letting yourself be tender?
 Well, you couldn’t make me do it

Some people are often more gentle, kind or “tender” toward things that are non-human such as animals/small creatures instead of their fellow humans. However, she protests against this reserved “tenderness” and opts for being kind to all.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: This connects back to her line in Relative Fiction, where she sings “Do I get callous or do I stay tender / Which of these is worse / And which is better?” Even when she’s around another person who is able to be vulnerable with her, she can’t make herself do the same. Staying callous is just too protective.
We took the 40 down to

The Interstate 40 is a major east-west highway that runs through the southern and central United States. It passes through Nashville, where Baker currently lives, to her hometown in Memphis, Tennessee.

search_results.title: Sprained Ankle
search_results.lyrics:
Sprained Ankle LyricsWish I could write songs about anything other than death
But I can't go to bed without drawing the red, shaving off breaths;
Each one so heavy, each one so cumbersome
Each one a lead weight hanging between my lungs
Spilling my guts, sweat on a microphone, breaking my voice
Whenever I'm alone with you, can't talk but
"Isn't this weather nice? Are you okay?"
Should I go somewhere else and hide my face?
A sprinter learning to wait
A marathon runner, my ankles are sprained
A marathon runner, my ankles are sprainedYou might also like12Embed

description.plain:
“Sprained Ankle”, a simple, honest track rested on a single guitar, sees Julien Baker working through recovery. In an extended metaphor, she wishing to be a “sprinter”, or solve her problems more easily, but comes to terms with her identity as a “marathon runner” whose “ankles are sprained”: an encumbered long-distance journeyer.

In 2018, NPR ranked this as the #156 greatest song by a female or nonbinary artist in the 21st century.

A music video was released along with the song on October 26, 2015.

body.plain:
“Sprained Ankle”, a simple, honest track rested on a single guitar, sees Julien Baker working through recovery. In an extended metaphor, she wishing to be a “sprinter”, or solve her problems more easily, but comes to terms with her identity as a “marathon runner” whose “ankles are sprained”: an encumbered long-distance journeyer.

In 2018, NPR ranked this as the #156 greatest song by a female or nonbinary artist in the 21st century.

A music video was released along with the song on October 26, 2015.

songs.artist_names: The National Symphony Orchestra (Ft. Gracie Folds)
songs.full_title: Sprained Ankle by The National Symphony Orchestra (Ft. Gracie Folds)
songs.title: Sprained Ankle

songs.full_title: Sprained Ankle (Audiotree Live Version) by Julien Baker
songs.title: Sprained Ankle (Audiotree Live Version)

annotations:
Each one so heavy, each one so cumbersome
 Each one a lead weight hanging between my lungs

Here Julien approaches the literal and figurative weight of her emotions. It’s not merely that breathing is hard because it’s rushed, but that each breath indexes something Julien needs to get off their chest, a “lead weight” that otherwise “hang[s] between [her] lungs.”

These lines can be connected to the rest of the song inasmuch as they refer to songs Julien writes to relieve her mental anguish. The rest of the song suggests she’s estranged from someone she cares about deeply.

A marathon runner, my ankles are sprained
 A marathon runner, my ankles are sprained

A marathon runner must be good at running, but with sprained ankles, it is impossible to run or even walk.  Similarly, it is the singer’s job to get out on stage and “spill her guts” in front of strangers, so opening up is something that she is uniquely good at. However, she finds it impossible to be open, and comfortable when speaking to the object of her affection.
A sprinter learning to wait

She’s eager for something, but knows that it might not be a good idea.

A sprinter must be very quick to run when the starter’s pistol is fired, so it is not a natural skill for them to be patient. Baker is saying that she is learning to be patient, but it is difficult for her.

Spilling my guts, sweat on a microphone, breaking my voice
 Whenever I’m alone with you, can’t talk but
 “Isn’t this weather nice? Are you okay?”
 Should I go somewhere else and hide my face?

Throughout the album, Julien’s lyrics reveal worries, insecurities, desires, personal anecdotes – as she notes here, she’s “spilling [her] guts” to her audience, being as forthright as possible. Julien has no problem exposing her vulnerabilities in her art.

When she finds herself alone with the person she loves, however, she avoids opening up to them and instead fixates on small talk. (“‘Isn’t this weather nice? Are you okay?’”)

The other party in the relationship may also be unwilling to breach such topics. In interviews, Julien has opened up about her struggles with depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation: taboos in many cultures, despite their ubiquity. The people in Julien’s life may feel intimidated by her transparency, resorting to pleasantries as a means of redirecting focus from the dark parts of the human experience.
But I can’t go to bed without drawing the red, shaving off breaths;

Given Julien’s openness about her former substance use, this line likely has to do with an addiction to cigarettes. The “red” refers to cherry of the cigarette; “shaving off breaths” may be an acknowledgement that the habit shortens her lifespan.

Alternatively, “drawing the red” could refer to the process of drawing blood into a syringe prior to injecting an intravenous drug, like heroin, to ensure contact with a vein. Like cigarettes, these drugs “shave off breaths” by adversely affecting the body.

She revisits this penchant for self-destruction in the next track, “Brittle Boned,” singing,

This will be quick and easy, I’m not gonna feel a thing…
‘Cause I’m so good at hurting myself
Wish I could write songs about anything other than death

She is acknowledging her own preoccupation with unhappiness; finally admitting she wants to be happier. As Julian herself explained in an interview, speaking about this particular line:

They’re not all about dying! Some of them are about almost dying or being afraid of death or a relationship dying. I remember exactly when I wrote that. I was sitting in my dorm and it was almost a joke with myself. I was just writing these sad, bummer songs, and it was like, What is wrong with me? Why can’t I feel better? I wish I could write about something happy. I wish I could write something other than songs about frickin’ death. What if I just say that lyric in the song? I texted the lyrics to one of my friends, and he was like, “I love it!” So I kept it and it’s good because it’s an endeavor of mine to write songs about more significant things. I don’t want to dwell on negativity, but you have to confront it. It’s a weird balance to find.

description.plain:
“Hardline” is the second single off Julien Baker’s third album, Little Oblivions.
Lyrically, it contains topics that are staples in Baker’s catalogue, such as substance abuse, depression and the burden of mercy. In musical terms, this song marks a further departure from the Tennessee singer-songwriter’s earlier, stripped-down sound, prominently featuring drums and uncharacteristically lush instrumental breaks. In an interview for KEXP, Julien Baker has said that when writing this song, she wanted it to be one “to bang your head to”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HS2TxfBSmjs

song.embed_content: Read “Hardline” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Hardline

body.plain:
“Hardline” is the second single off Julien Baker’s third album, Little Oblivions.
Lyrically, it contains topics that are staples in Baker’s catalogue, such as substance abuse, depression and the burden of mercy. In musical terms, this song marks a further departure from the Tennessee singer-songwriter’s earlier, stripped-down sound, prominently featuring drums and uncharacteristically lush instrumental breaks. In an interview for KEXP, Julien Baker has said that when writing this song, she wanted it to be one “to bang your head to”.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HS2TxfBSmjs

annotations:
Start asking for forgiveness in advance
 For all the future things I will destroy
 That way I can ruin everything
 When I do, you don’t get to act surprised

Here, although it’s appearing like Julien is asking for forgiveness to keep her relationships, it’s could really be a front for protecting herself and her loved ones. Even though she may be cognizant that an apology pre-incident isn’t truly an apology, she uses it as a way to prepare loved ones for her behaviours, as well as a way to distance herself and put up a wall. This in turn fuels her self-destructive behaviours, as loneliness is often a reason many “ruin” things.

I think this line also has a depressive hint in it, in which Julien is not yet fully accepting of recovery. The apologies hint that she knows her behaviour is harmful, but she is using them in order to continue the pattern of behaviour, rather than attempting to stop whatever actions she may be apologising for. This could be referring to her relapse, in which she no longer is actively trying to get better, but instead is trying to get away with “ruining everything”.

Blacked out on a weekday
 Still something that I’m trying to avoid

This opening lyric to the song and record introduces the idea seen throughout Little Oblivions of individuals avoiding their realities in exchange for “little oblivions”. On her sophomore album Turn Out The Lights, Julien seemed to  resolve that she was now able to move on from the issues that had caused her to fall into addiction. However, that was proven false when she relapsed near the end of 2018. Thus, Julien has returned to her coping mechanism of substance abuse to avoid whatever pain she continues to feel in her everyday life.

Say it’s not so cut and dry
 Oh, it isn’t black and white
 What if it’s all black, baby?
 All the time

The whole song revolves around crossing the “hardline” – about going from right to wrong. From good to bad, or – as it has been said for a long time – going from white to black. The idea of blackness being about the wrong is rooted in language for time in memoriam.

Here, the wrong takes over.

Suggesting that everything is black all the time is the most extreme way of looking at things pessimistically. It’s clear (or in black and white) that things are the worst they can be.

It also conjures images of the “black dog” of depression.



The idea of black and white in terms of wrong and right is also synonymous with the “gray area”, and in turn the idea of “crossing the line”.

Something being in black and white is also seen as clear and understandable – as is the term “cut and dry” – a foregone conclusion
Would you hit me this hard if I were a boy?

In an interview with iNews Julien expanded on this lyric,

“I feel like I was socialised around a lot of men, wanting to be performatively strong and tough because I had felt as a small 5ft tall 100lb lesbian that I was vulnerable.” It was about the queer body not feeling safe in a hetero world. “If I had been more physically intimidating, would I have been spared this experience? Would I have not hit this person because they were born a woman?”

I’m telling my own fortune
 Something I cannot escape
 I can see where this is going
 But I can’t find the brake

Describes the feeling of relapse, where one small act catapults you back into substance abuse. When you choose that act despite knowing what will happen, the awareness you have becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.

Took the fall, I draw a hard line
 When I cross it, it’s the third time

Prior to the composition of this album, Julien suffered a relapse into substance abuse. The hard line she’s drawing is abstinence; in this song, she predicts that she will cross it (making it the third time).
https://www.spin.com/2021/02/julien-baker-little-oblivions-interview/

See, I don’t need you to defend me
 ’Cause it’s just the sort of thing that I enjoy
This line is probably related to masochism, which can be defined as “to enjoy having pain inflicted on oneself” and is often considered to be overtly sexual, but it doesn’t necessarily have to be.

Until then, I’ll split the difference
 Between medicine and poison
 Take what I can get away with
 While it burns right through my stomach

Julien has struggled with addiction, but is many years sober. “Until then I’ll split the difference between medicine and poison” compares the substances she was abusing to both medicine and poison, and trying to determine whether she considers it to be medicine or poison, and presumably settles on the idea that it is both.

Say my own name in the mirror
 And when nobody appears

An allusion to the folklore of “Bloody Mary”, a ritual in which people can summon a spirit or ghost either friendly or evil by repeating her name (In popular culture this folklore was adapted into the “Candyman” film)



It also takes the idea of “being unable to recognize oneself” a step further, which is looking at yourself and not seeing anyone at all.

search_results.title: Something
search_results.lyrics:
Something LyricsI know you're sleeping by now
But I'm still up walking around
The walls of my skull bend backwards
And in like a labyrinth
And I knew I was wasting my time
Keep myself awake at night
'Cause whenever I close my eyes
I'm chasing your tail lights
In the dark
In the dark
In the dark
And I know you left hours ago
I still haven't moved yet
I knew you were gone months ago
But I can't think of anyone else
I should have said something, something, something
But I couldn't find something to say
So I just said nothing, nothing, nothing
Sat and watched you drive away

And I just let the parking lot swallow me up
Choking your tires, and kicking up dust
Asking aloud why you're leaving
But the pavement won't answer me

And I just let the silence swallow me up
The ring in my ears tastes like blood
Asking aloud why you're leaving
But the pavement won't answer me
And I know I meant nothing, nothing to you
But I thought I meant something, something, something
But I just said nothing, said nothing, said nothing
Sat and watched you drive away

Oh I just said nothing, said nothing, said nothing
I can't think of anyone, anyone else
I can't think of anyone, anyone else
I can't think of anyone, anyone else
I can't think of anyone, anyone else
No, I won't think of anyone elseYou might also like12Embed

description.plain: A song about l'esprit d'escalier – thinking of a perfect reply too late.  The song’s narrator wanted to say something that she couldn’t and lost someone who didn’t care for her.

song.embed_content: Read “Something” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Something

body.plain: A song about l'esprit d'escalier – thinking of a perfect reply too late.  The song’s narrator wanted to say something that she couldn’t and lost someone who didn’t care for her.

annotations:
Asking aloud why you’re leaving
 But the pavement won’t answer me
It sounds like Julien is talking to herself- “asking aloud,” “the pavement won’t answer me.”

And I know I meant nothing, nothing to you
 But I thought I meant something, something, something
 But I just said nothing, said nothing, said nothing
 Sat and watched you drive away

This bridge really sets the heartbreaking context of the rest of the song, making it clear that it’s not simply about not having the right words. As her voice swells accordingly, it’s here that she formally acknowledges the pain of feeling betrayed (or, at least, unrequited affection).

Jumping from “I thought I meant something” to “I just said nothing” serves to drive home her desperation in that critical moment preceding the song. She knows full well that the right words probably wouldn’t have saved the relationship, but in her pain, it’s easy to entertain the idea that everything could be okay. As is clear to us, though, it’s not really about that one moment, that’s just the culmination of everything before it.

The power of this song comes from how well Julien alludes to all of the various emotions jumping around in the aftermath of what was presumably a breakup. Here, it’s easier for her to cope by redirecting her anger at herself for not saying “the right words” than it is to face feeling worthless in the eyes of her love.
The ring in my ears tastes like blood

The silence from being alone in the parking lot is almost overwhelming her sense of hearing.  The accompanying physical reaction is reminiscent of getting punched in the face, but what’s really notable here isn’t the pain itself:

Where a lot of artists might say that “The silence is deafening,” Julien takes it a step further, noting the side effect of the trauma, the blood from facial injury. If there is an auditory equivalent to getting punched in the face, the silence from the absence of her love interest is it.
Choking your tires, and kicking up dust
She isn’t just left with her feelings and the memory of what just happened but the taste of the rubber from the tires of the departed car and the dust that was churned up by it leaving.
And I knew I was wasting my time
Even earlier in the relationship, she was aware that the relationship was doomed.  Nevertheless she was trying to make it work.  She was hopeful, but at the same time, pessimistic.

I should have said something, something, something
 But I couldn’t find something to say
 So I just said nothing, nothing, nothing

The linchpin stanza for the song comes here as (in)activity is equated to presence and absence–something and nothing. The speaker longs for substance to fulfill the desires of their own desire, the loved object. And yet, the speaker only finds lack, unable to ‘find something to say.’ The speaker, in a quest for presence, merely deploys absence: ‘nothing, nothing, nothing.’

This is the central paradox of the song, which the first stanza alerts the listener to. The song is a metaphorical labyrinth, a vessel that traps the loved object, and while the speaker purports to have ‘nothing’ to say, they in fact have produced presence from absence. Inactivity, saying ‘nothing,’ which cannot satisfy and retain the loved object and sustain the romance, produces activity, which is the song itself.

The inability to speak, especially in important moments or to important people, is a subject Julien has also touched in other songs such as Sprained Ankle.

Spilling my guts
Sweat on a microphone, breaking my voice
Whenever I’m alone with you, can’t talk but
“Isn’t this weather nice? Are you okay?”

I knew you were gone months ago
 But I can’t think of anyone else

The song continues emphasizing the tension between in/action, here considering how the relationship had ended long before the love object drove away. At the same time, there is an inability to actively move beyond this romance. Instead, the speaker actively insists upon their fixation: ‘I can’t think of anyone else.’ And yet this insistence is unproductive: the loved object is gone; the romance is over.

And I know you left hours ago
 I still haven’t moved yet

Again, the speaker contemplates their inaction in the face of their loss. The speaker seems completely undone by this loss–frozen, unable to move or do anything. One cannot help but be reminded of a line from Judith Butler’s Precarious Life:

‘When we lose certain people, or when we are dispossessed from a place, or a community, we may simply feel that we are undergoing something temporary, that mourning will be over and some restoration of prior order will be achieved. But maybe when we undergo what we do, something about who we are is revealed, something that delineates the ties we have to others, that shows us that these ties constitute what we are, ties or bonds that compose us. It is not as if an “I” exists independently over here and then simply loses a “you” over there, especially if the attachment to “you” is part of what composes who “I” am. If I lose you, under these conditions, then I not only mourn the loss, but I become inscrutable to myself. Who “am” I, without you? When we lose some of these ties by which we are constituted, we do not know who we are or what to do. On one level, I think I have lost “you” only to discover that “I” have gone missing as well.’

Indeed, the song insists on a Butlarian ethics that questions the grievability and unmournability of loss.

’Cause whenever I close my eyes
 I’m chasing your tail lights

As the speaker retreats into their labyrinth in order to think about their lost love, they imagine chasing after their love’s car. This romanticized imagery of disappearing tail lights might be traced back to Arcade Fire’s Headlights Look Like Diamonds, in which ‘tail lights burn like coal,’ or the ashy remnants of a once burning romance.

Beyond this, the couplet marks a tension between the action and inaction that runs throughout the song. In this moment of quiet reflection (inaction), the speaker imagines chasing (action) after their lover.

The walls of my skull bend backwards
 And in like a labyrinth

Perhaps the most famous labyrinth is western mythology belonged to King Minos’s and was designed by Daedalus to hold Minos’s bastard child, the minotaur. In contradistinction to a maze–a series of paths that leads to an exit–a labyrinth is contains no real end, less its entrance. It’s a symbol of futility and hopelessness.

As the song’s protagonist considers their relationship past, they feel their head begin to collapse in on itself, offering no way out; no new possibility for their relationship.

At the same time, the labyrinth is a metaphorical and physical vessel for the objects it holds: rather than killing his bastard son, Minos imprisons him in a space that paradoxically has an unattainable exit. In similar fashion, the song’s protagonist has fashioned, in their mind at least, a vessel for their loved object who has since left. This is reinforced in the final line of the song, in which the protagonist insists that they ‘won’t think of anyone else’

search_results.title: Relative Fiction
search_results.lyrics:
Relative Fiction Lyrics[Verse 1]
Midnight, you could see me dangling
Glow like a cherry falling, now it's a downpour
You could see me racing the rain to the ground floor
You're the only thing I'll wait around for
Maybe when you get off of work, you should meet me
We could go barreling down the main street
You could try watching while I run through the high-beams

[Bridge]
'Cause if I didn't have a mean bone in my body
I'd find some other way to cause you pain
I won't bother telling you I'm sorry
For something that I'm gonna do again
[Verse 2]
When I could spend the weekend out on a bender
Do I get callous or do I stay tender?
Which of these is worse and which is better?
Dying to myself, virtually a massacre
A character of somebody's invention
A martyr in another passion play
I guess I don't mind losing my conviction
If it's all relative fiction anyway

[Verse 3]
'Cause I don't need a savior, I need you to take me home
I don't need your help, I need you to leave me alone
I'm out where the drunks at the bar talk over the band
I try to express, I can't understand
I beat at the keys, I bloody my hands
'Til you hear me
I've got no business praying
I'm finished being good
Now I can finally be okay and not the way I thought I should
Mm-mmYou might also like2Embed

song.embed_content: Read “Relative Fiction” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Relative Fiction

annotations:
I’m out where the drunks at the bar talk over the band
 I try to express, I can’t understand

Cycles of addiction is a reoccurring theme of the album, again shown here. Even though the narrator is in a period of sobriety (presumably given she differentiates herself from “the drunks”), she still ends up at a bar due to her work.

There’s also a complete lack of communication. The drunks are talking over her performance rather than listening to, or even simply hearing, it. The narrator is also lost in her understanding, though it’s unclear whether it’s an understanding of her own feelings and/or impulses, or why no one is willing to listen, or  even her own expression after losing its meaning in translation. Either way, it’s leaving her disconnected.
Dying to myself, virtually a massacre

Committing suicide, or accidental death through self-destructive behaviours, could be seen as a massacre in which Julien is killing her entire self, which, relatively, is her whole world. This refers to the title too – relative fiction. In Julien causing her own death, she is destroying her whole world and everyone in it, even if logically she would only be killing one person.

I’ve got no business praying
 I’m finished being good
 Now I can finally be okay and not the way I thought I should

This refers to the narrator giving up on being “good” because they are “okay” with the pain they have, comfortable in the destructive world their mind has created for them. They are not better in any real sense, i.e. “not the way I thought I should”.

A character of somebody’s invention
 A martyr in another passion play
 I guess I don’t mind losing my conviction
 If it’s all relative fiction anyway

Julien is the subject of how other people perceive her and the narratives they may invent about her, be that fans or close friends. However, their view of her often as a tragic figure is not at all how she views herself. In fact, Julien has a propensity for believing the opposite about herself. Julien resolves though that it doesn’t matter anyway since even the own mythos she has held herself to as a “good Christian” was fiction.
I beat at the keys, I bloody my hands

The part of the line, “beat at the keys,” could be a reference to her playing piano. There is a piano part that comes through in the mix around the moment that lyric hits. She plays piano, and she plays guitar until her fingers bleed.

Bloody hands could also refer to fist fighting, as it is referenced in several of her other songs (Red Door, Shadowboxing, Even).
When I could spend the weekend out on a bender
A bender is an extended period of time spent drunk or high. It’s a specific kind of “little oblivion,” a few days of escape from reality in unconsciousness.

You’re the only thing I’ll wait around for
 Maybe when you get off of work, you should meet me
 We could go barreling down the main street

This is a bit of a double-edged set of lines. On the one hand, Julien relates to the unnamed person (or God) that they represent a barrier between her and succumbing to her self-destructive ways, although she then goes on to say that she and the person could “go barreling down the main street” together, seeming to indicate that the cycle of self-destruction isn’t going to stop.

In addition, the mention of a threat of suicide, immediately followed by the statement that X person is the only thing that could help her, is akin to the parasuicidal behavior of those with Borderline Personality Disorder, wherein an intense fear of abandonment prompts dramatic statements of hopelessness (“you’re my only hope of making it out alive”) in a misguided attempt to keep people around.

Midnight, you could see me dangling
 Glow like a cherry falling, now it’s a downpour
 You could see me racing the rain to the ground floor

TW: Suicide

This imagery represents that of someone who is about to go over the edge (either literally, as a “cherry falling” – such as someone about to jump from a ledge – or figuratively); the idea of “racing rain to the ground floor” again brings to mind the image of someone having jumped to their death.

I won’t bother telling you I’m sorry
 For something that I’m gonna do again

Julien is self-aware enough to recognize that the decisions she makes are often out of her power, such that apologizing will only come across as shallow in light of the inevitability of her messing up again.

’Cause if I didn’t have a mean bone in my body
 I’d find some other way to cause you pain
This alludes to the all-too-common phenomenon of well-intentioned people hurting those around them with the ramifications of under-treated mental illness and addiction.

description.plain: This song is about loving someone who is dependent on substances while also having your own problems, which you feel is a burden on them and theirs. The love seems to be unrequited, or at least the person is unable to handle a relationship with her, or anyone.

song.embed_content: Read “Sour Breath” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Sour Breath

album.full_title: Turn Out the Lights by Julien Baker
album.name: Turn Out the Lights

body.plain: This song is about loving someone who is dependent on substances while also having your own problems, which you feel is a burden on them and theirs. The love seems to be unrequited, or at least the person is unable to handle a relationship with her, or anyone.

songs.full_title: Sour Breath by The Devil Wears Prada
songs.title: Sour Breath

annotations: Watch the poison leak from your pores

“Poison” is a term often used for alcohol. The origin of sayings such as “Pick your poison” comes from poison being used as slang while telling people to choose an alcoholic beverage. In many depictions, alcohol is shown with caution or warning labels as if it’s poisonous. One iconic depiction is moonshine, which would be marked with an X per distillation, with each distillation increasing the alcoholic content. Three Xs meant it had been distilled three times, practically rendering pure alcohol.

Additionally, consuming high amounts of something aromatic can lead to smelling like that substance. Alcoholics frequently smell like alcohol due to this, even when freshly showered, as the body can deal with the excess alcohol by pushing it through the skin.

Baker is saying that their partner drinks so heavily she can practically see the alcohol seeping out of their pores. It’s both a gruesome visual and a testament to the damage her partner’s alcoholism is doing to them.
And I thought that if I tried a little bit harder you’d change your mind

A common delusion among people in toxic relationships is that they bear sole responsibility for the relationship’s success or failure. Here the speaker tries to take responsibility for their partner’s change of mind. ‘She doesn’t love me enough, this is my fault’.

Splinter in my arm where you rest your head
 Checking my watch till you come to bed

This is a juxtaposition of pain and longing.

The “splinter in [her] arm” is a thematic parallel to the wooden home she built in her partner’s chest (referenced in the previous line). Her partner rests their head on Julien’s arm where a splinter is – at once affectionate and endearing while simultaneously applying painful pressure to a wound. The second line further emphasizes her persistent longing; in spite of the pain, she still wants her partner. This relationship is multi-dimensional: it takes the form of comfort while exacerbating some existing pain.

But I shouldn’t have built a house in the middle of your chest
 Plywood boards joined at your breast

This line could be a reference to Audre Lorde’s poem “Woman,” from The Black Unicorn:



The imagery suggests the speaker’s feeling of having established too much of herself in her partner. She’s overdependent, having figuratively ‘built a house’ right inside their partner’s body.

Oh, the harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink
 The harder I swim, the faster I sink

The harder Julien tries to fix her toxic relationship and her and her partner’s problems, the worse Julien suffers. This causes her to not act and stay stuck in an unhappy situation because there is no way for her to improve it. She is doomed to suffer in a bad situation until it implodes.

Leave me inside in a body made of wood
 In a body made of wood

This alludes back to the line about “Plywood boards joined at your breast” and the concept of construction and attempting to build a home out of this person, in a metaphorical sense.

A body of wood is also flammable, meaning it is susceptible to being burned down.
Burn everything down to prove you could

This person hurt her just because they could, to show the power they had.

Manipulation is a tool often used in both emotionally and physically abusive relationships. The person in power corners the victim in a relationship into doing something against their wishes to twist them into feeling helpless against the power of the abuser. The subject of this line is showing the power that they have over Julien, making her feel powerless.
Think all the liquor’s gonna keep you warm

This person is dependent on alcohol and other substances. They are under the impression that the alcohol will keep them happy or content. Presumably to “escape” their problems.

Liquor, typically highly alcoholic, is sometimes said to create a warm sensation in the stomach of the person who consumes it. However, this does nothing to a person’s core body temperature. Julien may be referring to this deceiving phenomena in this line, giving a double meaning to the “warm[th]” alluded to.
You’re everything I want and I’m all you dread

She is so deeply in love with this person but she feels to this person she is nothing but a burden and the person dreads being around her.
She specifically discusses this lyric in an interview with Pitchfork:

Pitchfork: Your lyrics often involve paradoxical ideas, and on this song you say, “You’re everything I want, and I’m all you dread.”
Baker: I’m looking at how different people’s experiences of a situation can be: How you can think that something is right for you, but it’s totally wrong for someone else, or how you can want and not want something at the same time. Especially in relationships. Everybody wants to have an empirical analysis of a relationship ending, but sometimes there’s not that much clarity, and that’s OK.

Kiss me goodnight with your sour breath
 Breaks on my face like a wave of emptiness

The person she’s sharing a bed with approaches her (after leaving her waiting for so long) with the harsh smell of alcohol hanging on their breath. The bitter scent hits the speaker, and has the effect of making her feel isolated; and worried for the seeming void in her partner.

search_results.title: Go Home

Go Home LyricsI went walking again, I'll go out
And forget to tell any of my friends where I'm going

"I'm sorry for asking, but please, come take me home"
I quit talking again but I know you're still listening
To see if I sleep or I pierce my skin
Needles to the worn-out rags
The folds in my arms, the sickening black

Lock all the cabinets and send me to bed

'Cause I'm alone again and I don't like the things I see
And I haven't been taking my meds
So lock all the cabinets, and send me to bed
'Cause I know you're still worried I'm gonna get scared again
And make my insides clean with your kitchen bleach
But I've kissed enough bathroom sinks
To make up for the lovers that never loved me

God, I wanna go homeYou might also like8Embed

description.plain:
At the end Julien is playing “In Christ Alone”, a modern Christian song, and you can hear a preacher speaking in the background. As she explained in an interview with Stereogum the latter was actually a coincidence:

We were recording that track, and the end is the piano arrangement from this hymn called “In Christ Alone.” It holds a lot of memories for me — being young in church, and the lyrics hold a lot of meaning when you analyze them. It’s nostalgic, and as I was recording the end of that we had these two directional mics set up while I played piano into the pre-amp. And then I hear this like, crackly TV noise and the dialogue happening through my headphones. Well, it wasn’t dialogue but the guy was talking. I just finish off the thing, the arrangement and everyone tells me that the pre-amp was picking up church radio, as I was playing. […] It was like a Twilight Zone thing, and I decided to leave it in there because it was such a cool, organic happening. It’s just so crazy, given the context of the record, that this happened to be a quintessential Southern preacher shouting phrases that start with: “But, God!” [laughs] almost like Reverend Lovejoy from The Simpsons. It was like some holy roller shit.

song.embed_content: Read “Go Home” by Julien Baker on Genius
song.title: Go Home

body.plain:
At the end Julien is playing “In Christ Alone”, a modern Christian song, and you can hear a preacher speaking in the background. As she explained in an interview with Stereogum the latter was actually a coincidence:

We were recording that track, and the end is the piano arrangement from this hymn called “In Christ Alone.” It holds a lot of memories for me — being young in church, and the lyrics hold a lot of meaning when you analyze them. It’s nostalgic, and as I was recording the end of that we had these two directional mics set up while I played piano into the pre-amp. And then I hear this like, crackly TV noise and the dialogue happening through my headphones. Well, it wasn’t dialogue but the guy was talking. I just finish off the thing, the arrangement and everyone tells me that the pre-amp was picking up church radio, as I was playing. […] It was like a Twilight Zone thing, and I decided to leave it in there because it was such a cool, organic happening. It’s just so crazy, given the context of the record, that this happened to be a quintessential Southern preacher shouting phrases that start with: “But, God!” [laughs] almost like Reverend Lovejoy from The Simpsons. It was like some holy roller shit.

annotations: The folds in my arms, the sickening black

Again referencing the “black ink” of drugs that she sings about in other songs.

Track marks left after shooting up can become black.
God, I wanna go home

This line is a circle back to the first verse. Now instead of being helpless due to intoxication she is helpless due to loneliness and fear. Just like she had to rely on the grace of someone who was sober to come take her to safety, now on a deeper, more spiritual level she has to rely on someone who does not have the same soul-condition that is causing this loneliness and pain to rescue her. She decides, in this line, to call her Father.

The end of the song continues with “In Christ Alone” which seems to be the resolution of the song/album. She has looked everywhere for something to satisfy: music, relationships, intoxication to name a few. Christ is the only one metaphorically sober enough to rescue her from her metaphoric ditch. A sober person has nothing to gain in helping someone in a ditch find their way home. In this case Christ is only motivated by Julien’s well being and having an eternal relationship with her.

“In Christ alone my hope is found
He is my light, my strength, my song
This Cornerstone, this solid ground
Firm through the fiercest drought and storm
What heights of love, what depths of peace
When fears are stilled, when strivings cease
My Comforter, my All in All
Here in the love of Christ I stand”

(the preacher talking in the background was an accident so you interpret that as you please)

And I know my body is just dirty clothes
 I’m tired of washing my hands

In this line her body represents her life now and just like you take off dirty clothes in a short time, Julien’s body will die in about 65 years from now or sooner but her spirit will live on. As a Christian knowing what freedom you will have when you are free from loneliness and fear in heaven, it makes it all the harder to live out your purpose on earth surrounded by pain and suffering. If you knew your body was temporary washing your hands seems useless.

A more literal interpretation would be that she can’t change her clothes so she just says in the ones she wore the day before. She doesn’t see the point anymore. She’s tired and wants to go home.

The song could be about addiction or about someone with crippling OCD. She sees herself in this line as made up entirely of dirt and filth, and is sick and tired of seeing herself that way and trying to clean herself up, when she knows she will only ever be top dirty to quell her disease.

A common symptom of OCD is ritualistically and/or repetitively washing ones hands, perhaps to rid some invisible filth only the sufferer still sees on themselves. If she sees her body as dirty, though no amount of hand washing will ‘clean’ her enough to satisfy the disorder, it is a developed coping mechanism. The reference to ‘clean[ing her] insides’ with bleach, a disinfectant that is toxic when consumed, also supports this connection in her mind that self-harming = purifying.
So lock all the cabinets, and send me to bed
Locking the cabinets and sending her to bed isn’t just for her own safety, it’s for her protector’s peace of mind.

The strung out call I make
 Burned down on the edge of the highway
 “I’m sorry for asking, but please, come take me home”

This is both a call for a ride and a proverbial “call for help.” Her drunken, despairing wanderings have led her somewhere too far to walk home from, and she realizes she needs someone to come get her. She calls her friends for a ride and waits on the edge of a highway, feeling terrible.

At the same time, she starts to realize that her substance abuse is starting to take its toll, and she needs to seek help.

The “please, come take me home” is echoed later in the song, when the singer is calling out to God to take her to the afterlife, her eternal home.

I’m just drunk on the side of the road in a ditch
 When you find me –

In recovery groups, rock bottom is the term used to describe the absolute lowest point of substance abuse. A stereotypical story of rock bottom involve someone waking up in a ditch or in the street, which can then become a starting point for recovery.
More tar than air in my lungs;

This line refers to habitual smoking of cigarettes or black tar heroin (or both). Respiratory complications–including lung abscesses, pneumonia, tuberculosis, and damaged air passages–are among the many health risks associated with chronic smoking.

And I haven’t been taking my meds
 Lock all the cabinets and send me to bed
 ’Cause I know you’re still worried I’m gonna get scared
 ’Cause I’m alone again and I don’t like the things I see

Here, the speaker admits to deviating from their medication regime, warning whoever they’re speaking to that they should ‘Lock all the cabinets’ and ‘send [her] to bed,’ probably for fear that the speaker will attempt to overdose. This is evident from the final two lines in the stanza when the speaker identifies their interlocutor’s worry with her own experience of not ‘lik[ing] the things [she] sees.’ This final line makes it seem that the combination of depression and lack of medication is leading to these sort of thoughts.

But the final line is hard to disentangle on syntax alone: does the speaker feel this way (alone, not liking what they’re seeing), or is that simply what their interlocutor thinks (‘Cause I know you’re still worried,’ she insists). On the one hand, the first verse is a fairly explicit cry for help, or at least remembering when the speaker begged their interlocutor for help. On the other hand, this line seems more like a summary of the interlocutor’s worries than the speaker’s own. Perhaps the turn in the final stanza, ‘But I’ve kissed enough bathroom sinks…’ suggests that the speaker has already turned a new leaf and learned from their mistakes.

There’s a song by Forrister, Julien’s other band, named Choked Up that came out in early 2015, with a similar section. In that,  Julien sings

So if I’m being honest, I’ve been taking my medicine.
Wasted, stay the nights on your floor in my clothes.
You hide all your knives; the bad dreams and the whiskey.
Tell your friends don’t miss me,
I know you don’t. Why would you?

.

But I know you’re still listening
 To see if I sleep or I pierce my skin
 Needles to the worn-out rags

Despite her vocal silence, whoever she’s talking about continues to listen to more self destructive behavior (‘pierce my skin / Needles to the worn out rags’ [perhaps the shift from injections to inhalants]).

 Here someone (“you”) is taking care of her, helping her to recover from addiction or depression.  This person is listening to see if she sleeps or if she engages in more self-destructive behavior.
I quit talking again

There’s a strange irony to this line that undercuts her actions above: she’s found by someone when she’s hammered, lungs filled with smoke, perhaps a little strung out, and second stanza instead begins with her ‘quit[ing] talking.’ At the same time, the line registers a self-destructive or depressive personality, which dovetails into the next line.

‘Quit[ing] talking’ could literally refer to ceasing to speak, i.e. selective mutism, a condition that can occur in response to trauma, as a symptom of PTSD. It could also simply be metaphorical, in that she has stopped fully and honestly communicating, hiding internal problems from those around her.
 An alternative explanation might be that in the first stanza she recognizes that she needs help from God and calls out to him, but she stops praying to God for help, likely falling back into old habits when she says quits talking again.
